title.value: Two types of human TCR differentially regulate reactivity to self and non-self antigens
title.justification: The title of the paper summarizes the study's focus on understanding how different types of human TCRs influence immune responses.
title.quote: Two types of human TCR differentially regulate reactivity to self and non-self antigens

extractions.description: This paper analyzes TCR sequences from over 1,000 individuals to identify two types of TCR repertoires - neonatal and TDT-dependent. It examines how these repertoires develop, persist, and contribute to immune responses against pathogens and autoantigens, as well as their role in conditions such as graft-versus-host disease.

type.justification: The paper involves the analysis of TCR sequences from a large cohort of individuals, focusing on observed data and patterns related to TCR diversity and functionality.
type.quote: Based on analyses of TCR sequences from over 1,000 individuals, we report that the TCR repertoire is composed of two ontogenically and functionally distinct types of TCRs.

name.justification: The research is centered around the T-cell receptor (TCR) repertoires, which are fundamental components of the human immune system.
name.quote: This report analyzed the amino acid sequence of over 100 million TCR CDR3 beta chains from over 1,000 subjects.

name.justification: The study utilizes bioinformatic methods to analyze large datasets of TCR sequences, extracting functional insights from sequence features.
name.quote: We then used the software IgBLAST (Ye et al., 2013) to obtain the number of mismatched (i.e., not germline) nucleotides in each CDR3aa sequence.

name.justification: The paper explores the genetic underpinnings of TCR diversity, its generation, and its impact on immune responses.
name.quote: These neonatal TCRs persist (or are continuously replenished) throughout life, are highly shared among subjects, and are likely polyreactive to self and microbial HLA-associated peptides.

name.justification: McPAS-TCR is used to assess sharing in the context of pathology-specific TCR sequences.
name.quote: Next, we downloaded and explored the McPAS database, a manually curated catalog of pathology-associated TCR sequences (Tickotsky et al., 2017).

referenced_paper_title.value: McPAS-TCR: a manually curated catalogue of pathology-associated T cell receptor sequences
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to McPAS-TCR in the paper indicates its usage in their analysis related to disease-specific TCR sequences.
referenced_paper_title.quote: From the McPAS CDR3 datasets, we downloaded the McPAS database on 2021-08-12 (Tickotsky et al., 2017).

name.justification: IgBLAST is used to align sequences and count mismatches with germline sequences.
name.quote: We then used the software IgBLAST (Ye et al., 2013) to obtain the number of mismatched (i.e., not germline) nucleotides in each CDR3aa sequence.

referenced_paper_title.value: IgBLAST: An immunoglobulin variable domain sequence analysis tool
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for IgBLAST provides context and validation for its use in TCR sequence analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: IgBLAST: An immunoglobulin variable domain sequence analysis tool.

name.justification: MIXCR is employed for isolating CDR3 contigs from RNA sequencing reads.
name.quote: To extract CDR3 sequences from RNA sequencing reads, we used the MIXCR software (Bolotin et al., 2015; Li et al., 2017).

referenced_paper_title.value: MiXCR: software for comprehensive adaptive immunity profiling
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper cites MIXCR as the tool used for CDR3 sequence extraction from RNA data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: MiXCR: software for comprehensive adaptive immunity profiling.

name.justification: OLGA is used for predicting CDR3 recombination probability, enhancing the analysis of TCR sequences.
name.quote: Using the OLGA software (see STAR Methods), we calculated the probability of a CDR3 nucleotide sequence being generated during V(D)J recombination for individual CDR3aa sequences.

referenced_paper_title.value: OLGA: fast computation of generation probabilities of B- and T-cell receptor amino acid sequences and motifs
referenced_paper_title.justification: OLGA is referenced for its application in computing CDR3 generation probabilities, supporting sequence analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: OLGA: fast computation of generation probabilities of B- and T-cell receptor amino acid sequences and motifs.
